title: Create EventStore Table
content:
Step 1: Open DynamoDB Console In the AWS Management Console, search for DynamoDB. Click DynamoDB to open the service. Step 2: Create Table Click Create table. Enter Table name: EventStore Enter Partition key: aggregateId (String) Enter Sort key: eventId (String) Select Default settings. Click Create table. ‚úÖ Result: The EventStore table will be created with aggregateId and eventId as keys.
Step 3: Create Global Secondary Index After the EventStore table is created, you need to add a Global Secondary Index for efficient querying.
In the EventStore table, click on the Indexes tab.
Click Create index button. Configure the Global Secondary Index:
Partition key: aggregateId (String) Sort key: timestamp (String) Index name: AggregateIndex Data type: Keep both as String Capacity mode: On-demand (default) Leave other settings as default and click Create index. ‚úÖ Result: The EventStore table is now ready with:
Primary key: aggregateId (Partition) + eventId (Sort) Global Secondary Index: AggregateIndex with aggregateId (Partition) + timestamp (Sort) On-demand capacity mode for automatic scaling
This setup allows efficient querying of events both by individual event ID and by aggregate with time-based ordering.

title: DEPLOYING A SERVERLESS ORDERING SYSTEM WITH EVENT SOURCING ON AWS
content:
DEPLOYING A SERVERLESS ORDERING SYSTEM WITH EVENT SOURCING ON AWS Overall In this workshop, you’ll learn the fundamentals and practical implementation of Event Sourcing Pattern using AWS Serverless services. Build a complete fastfood ordering system with instant event processing, state reconstruction, and comprehensive monitoring.
Content Introduction Preparation Create Event Store (DynamoDB) Deploy Lambda Functions Setup EventBridge Pipeline Config API Gateway Deploy Frontend Application Testing & Monitoring Clean up resources

title: Implement OrderCommandHandler
content:
In this section, we will implement the OrderCommandHandler Lambda function that processes order-related commands from our fast food ordering system. This function will handle order placement, confirmation, and cancellation operations.
Step 1: Open Lambda Console In the AWS Management Console, search for Lambda. Click Lambda to open the service. Step 2: Create Lambda Function Click Create function. Select Author from scratch.
Enter Function name: OrderCommandHandler.
Select Runtime: Python 3.12.
Select Architecture: x86_64.
Expand Change default execution role.
Select Use an existing role.
Choose EventSourcingLambdaRole from the dropdown.
Click Create function. Step 3: Implement Function Code In the Code source section of the OrderCommandHandler function, replace the default code with the following: import json import boto3 import uuid from datetime import datetime, timedelta from decimal import Decimal # Initialize AWS clients dynamodb = boto3.resource('dynamodb') eventbridge = boto3.client('events') # DynamoDB tables event_store_table = dynamodb.Table('EventStore') menu_items_table = dynamodb.Table('MenuItems') def lambda_handler(event, context): try: # Parse request http_method = event['httpMethod'] path = event['path'] body = json.loads(event['body']) if event.get('body') else {} print(f"Processing {http_method} {path}") print(f"Body: {body}") if path == '/orders' and http_method == 'POST': return handle_place_order(body) elif path == '/orders/confirm' and http_method == 'POST': return handle_confirm_order(body) elif path == '/orders/cancel' and http_method == 'POST': return handle_cancel_order(body) else: return build_response(404, {'error': 'Endpoint not found'}) except Exception as e: print(f"Error: {str(e)}") import traceback traceback.print_exc() return build_response(500, {'error': 'Internal server error'}) def handle_place_order(order_data): # Validate order data required_fields = ['customerName', 'customerPhone', 'customerAddress', 'items'] if not all(field in order_data for field in required_fields): return build_response(400, {'error': 'Missing required fields'}) # Validate items if not order_data['items'] or len(order_data['items']) == 0: return build_response(400, {'error': 'Order must contain at least one item'}) # Generate order ID order_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) # Calculate total amount total_amount = Decimal('0') validated_items = [] for item in order_data['items']: if 'itemId' not in item or 'quantity' not in item: return build_response(400, {'error': 'Each item must have itemId and quantity'}) # Get item price from menu try: menu_item = menu_items_table.get_item(Key={'itemId': item['itemId']}) if 'Item' not in menu_item: return build_response(400, {'error': f'Item {item["itemId"]} not found'}) menu_item_data = menu_item['Item'] if not menu_item_data.get('available', False): return build_response(400, {'error': f'Item {item["itemId"]} is not available'}) item_price = Decimal(str(menu_item_data['price'])) quantity = int(item['quantity']) item_total = item_price * quantity total_amount += item_total validated_items.append({ 'itemId': item['itemId'], 'name': menu_item_data['name'], 'price': item_price, # Keep as Decimal for DynamoDB 'quantity': quantity, 'image': menu_item_data.get('image', ''), 'total': item_total # Keep as Decimal for DynamoDB }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error processing item {item['itemId']}: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': f'Error processing item {item["itemId"]}'}) # Create OrderPlaced event event_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) timestamp = datetime.utcnow().isoformat() event_data = { 'eventId': event_id, 'aggregateId': order_id, 'eventType': 'OrderPlaced', 'eventData': { 'orderId': order_id, 'customerName': order_data['customerName'], 'customerPhone': order_data['customerPhone'], 'customerAddress': order_data['customerAddress'], 'items': validated_items, 'totalAmount': total_amount, # Keep as Decimal for DynamoDB 'status': 'PLACED', 'timestamp': timestamp }, 'timestamp': timestamp, 'version': 1 } try: # Store event in Event Store event_store_table.put_item(Item=event_data) print(f"Event stored successfully in EventStore") # Publish event to EventBridge (convert Decimals to float for JSON serialization) publish_event_to_bridge(event_data) print(f"Event published to EventBridge successfully") return build_response(201, { 'orderId': order_id, 'message': 'Order placed successfully', 'totalAmount': float(total_amount), # Convert to float for JSON response 'items': convert_decimals_to_float(validated_items), # Convert for JSON response 'status': 'PLACED' }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error storing event: {str(e)}") import traceback traceback.print_exc() return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to process order'}) def handle_confirm_order(confirm_data): order_id = confirm_data.get('orderId') if not order_id: return build_response(400, {'error': 'Order ID required'}) # Calculate estimated delivery time (30 minutes from now) estimated_delivery = (datetime.utcnow() + timedelta(minutes=30)).isoformat() # Create OrderConfirmed event event_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) timestamp = datetime.utcnow().isoformat() event_data = { 'eventId': event_id, 'aggregateId': order_id, 'eventType': 'OrderConfirmed', 'eventData': { 'orderId': order_id, 'confirmedAt': timestamp, 'estimatedDelivery': estimated_delivery, 'status': 'CONFIRMED' }, 'timestamp': timestamp, 'version': 1 } try: # Store event event_store_table.put_item(Item=event_data) # Publish event publish_event_to_bridge(event_data) return build_response(200, { 'message': 'Order confirmed successfully', 'estimatedDelivery': estimated_delivery }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error confirming order: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to confirm order'}) def handle_cancel_order(cancel_data): order_id = cancel_data.get('orderId') reason = cancel_data.get('reason', 'Customer request') if not order_id: return build_response(400, {'error': 'Order ID required'}) # Create OrderCancelled event event_id = str(uuid.uuid4()) timestamp = datetime.utcnow().isoformat() event_data = { 'eventId': event_id, 'aggregateId': order_id, 'eventType': 'OrderCancelled', 'eventData': { 'orderId': order_id, 'cancelledAt': timestamp, 'reason': reason, 'status': 'CANCELLED' }, 'timestamp': timestamp, 'version': 1 } try: # Store event event_store_table.put_item(Item=event_data) # Publish event publish_event_to_bridge(event_data) return build_response(200, { 'message': 'Order cancelled successfully', 'reason': reason }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error cancelling order: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to cancel order'}) def publish_event_to_bridge(event_data): try: # Convert Decimal values to float for JSON serialization event_data_for_bridge = convert_decimals_to_float(event_data['eventData']) print(f"Publishing event to EventBridge: {event_data['eventType']}") print(f"Event data: {event_data_for_bridge}") response = eventbridge.put_events( Entries=[ { 'Source': 'fastfood.orders', 'DetailType': event_data['eventType'], 'Detail': json.dumps(event_data_for_bridge, default=str), 'EventBusName': 'FastFoodOrderBus' } ] ) print(f"EventBridge response: {response}") # Check if there were any failures if response.get('FailedEntryCount', 0) > 0: print(f"Failed to publish some events: {response.get('Entries', [])}") raise Exception("Failed to publish event to EventBridge") except Exception as e: print(f"Error publishing event to EventBridge: {str(e)}") import traceback traceback.print_exc() raise def convert_decimals_to_float(obj): """ Recursively convert Decimal objects to float for JSON serialization """ if isinstance(obj, list): return [convert_decimals_to_float(item) for item in obj] elif isinstance(obj, dict): return {key: convert_decimals_to_float(value) for key, value in obj.items()} elif isinstance(obj, Decimal): return float(obj) else: return obj def build_response(status_code, body): return { 'statusCode': status_code, 'headers': { 'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*', 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods': 'GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS', 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers': 'Content-Type, Authorization' }, 'body': json.dumps(body, default=str) } Click Deploy to save the function code. ‚úÖ Result: The OrderCommandHandler Lambda function is successfully created and ready to process order commands.

title: Introduction
content:
üéØ Event Sourcing Pattern is an architectural pattern within distributed system design that stores all changes to application state as a sequence of immutable events, rather than just maintaining current state. This approach provides complete auditability and traceability without traditional database updates or deletions. Event Sourcing also makes it easy to comply with regulatory requirements that demand full audit trails, strict data governance practices, and completely traceable business operations with detailed event logs, while still providing developers with powerful state reconstruction capabilities and real-time event processing for modern applications.
Core Principles:
Immutable Events: Each change is recorded as an unchangeable event Append-Only Storage: Events are only added, never updated or deleted State Reconstruction: Current state is calculated by replaying events Complete History: Maintains the entire history of system changes This approach provides complete auditability, historical traceability, and regulatory compliance that demands detailed audit trails, while offering flexible state reconstruction capabilities and real-time event processing for modern applications. üîÄ CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation) Event Sourcing is commonly combined with CQRS Pattern for performance optimization:
What is CQRS?
Command: Handles write operations (Create, Update, Delete) Query: Handles read operations (Read) Responsibility Segregation: Separates read and write responsibilities Benefits of CQRS + Event Sourcing:
Independent Read/Write Optimization: Read models and Write models can be optimized separately Scalability: Scale read and write operations independently Flexibility: Multiple different read models from the same event store Performance: Queries optimized for specific use cases Event Sourcing vs CRUD Comparison Aspect CRUD Event Sourcing Data Storage Stores current state Stores event sequence Data Loss Loses history on update Maintains complete history Audit Trail Requires separate implementation Built-in automatically Complexity Simple More complex Read Performance Fast for simple queries Highly optimized with read models Write Performance Potential bottlenecks Append-only, faster Scalability Limited High, independent scaling Debugging Difficult to trace history Easy to debug and replay Consistency ACID transactions Eventual consistency The overall architecture of the system we will build: ‚òÅÔ∏è Architecture Components Description üîÑ Main Workflow: Client Request
Client sends requests through CloudFront (global CDN) CloudFront caches static content and routes dynamic requests API Gateway
Receives requests from CloudFront Handles authentication, rate limiting, request validation Routes requests to appropriate Lambda functions Command Handler (Lambda)
Processes business logic for write operations Validates commands and generates events Appends events to EventStore (DynamoDB) Event Processing Pipeline
EventBridge: Event routing and filtering with “OrderEventBus” rule CloudWatch + X-RAY: Monitoring and distributed tracing Routes events to appropriate processors Event Storage & Replay
EventStore (DynamoDB): Stores immutable events Replay Lambda: Replays events when state rebuild is needed ReadModel (DynamoDB): Materialized views optimized for queries Query Processing
Query Lambda: Handles read operations from ReadModel SNS: Notifications and event publishing üîß Serverless Technologies Used Service Role AWS Lambda Command/Query Handlers EventBridge Event Bus & Routing DynamoDB Event Store & Read Models API Gateway REST API Endpoints S3 + CloudFront Static Website Hosting CloudWatch Monitoring & Logging X-Ray Distributed Tracing SNS Pub/Sub Messaging üöÄ By the end of this hands-on workshop, you’ll have practical experience building resilient, audit-compliant systems using Event Sourcing and CQRS patterns, and the confidence to architect your own serverless applications that handle complex business workflows with complete traceability.

title: Configure EventBridge Rules
content:
In this section, we will create an EventBridge rule that supports our Event Sourcing architecture by capturing domain events from our custom event bus. This rule will route order events (OrderPlaced, OrderConfirmed, OrderCancelled) to our Lambda function, which will process these events to update read models and maintain the event store - a key component of Event Sourcing pattern.
Step 1: Navigate to EventBridge Rules In the Amazon EventBridge console, click Rules in the left navigation panel. Click Create rule. Step 2: Define Rule Details Name: OrderEventProcessingRule Description: Process all order events Event bus: Select FastFoodOrderBus from the dropdown Rule type: Select Rule with an event pattern Click Next. Step 3: Build Event Pattern Creation method: Select Custom pattern (JSON editor) In the Event pattern text area, enter the following JSON: { "source": ["fastfood.orders"], "detail-type": [ "OrderPlaced", "OrderConfirmed", "OrderCancelled" ] } Verify that JSON is valid indicator shows a green checkmark. Click Next. Step 4: Configure Target Target type: Select AWS service Select a service: Choose Lambda function Function: Select OrderEventProcessor from the dropdown Leave other settings as default. Click Next. Step 5: Configure Tags (Optional) This step is optional. You can add tags to organize and track your EventBridge rule. Click Next to proceed. Step 6: Review and Create Review all the configuration details:
Rule name: OrderEventProcessingRule Event bus: FastFoodOrderBus Event pattern: Captures fastfood.orders events Target: OrderEventProcessor Lambda function Click Create rule. ‚úÖ Result: The EventBridge rule is successfully created and will automatically route order events from the FastFoodOrderBus to the OrderEventProcessor Lambda function for processing.
Create StateReconstructionRule Now we’ll create a second rule for handling state reconstruction requests.
Step 7: Create Second Rule Click Create rule again to create another rule. Configure the rule details: Name: StateReconstructionRule Description: Handle state reconstruction requests Event bus: Select FastFoodOrderBus from the dropdown Rule type: Select Rule with an event pattern Click Next. Step 8: Build Event Pattern for State Reconstruction Creation method: Select Custom pattern (JSON editor) In the Event pattern text area, enter the following JSON: { "source": ["fastfood.orders"], "detail-type": [ "OrderPlaced", "OrderConfirmed", "OrderCancelled" ] } Verify that JSON is valid indicator shows a green checkmark. Click Next.
Step 9: Configure Target for State Reconstruction Target type: Select AWS service Select a service: Choose Lambda function Function: Select StateReconstructionHandler from the dropdown Leave other settings as default. Click Next. Step 10: Review and Create State Reconstruction Rule Review all the configuration details:
Rule name: StateReconstructionRule Event bus: FastFoodOrderBus Event pattern: Captures fastfood.orders events Target: StateReconstructionHandler Lambda function üìå Important: In the screenshot above, the Rule ARN is just an example.
Please copy the Rule ARN from your StateReconstructionRule in your AWS account.
You can find it in the EventBridge console ‚Üí Click your rule ‚Üí Rule ARN (highlighted in the red box).
Configure Lambda Function Permissions After creating the EventBridge rule, we need to ensure our Lambda function has the proper permissions to be invoked by EventBridge.
Navigate to Lambda Console ‚Üí Functions ‚Üí StateReconstructionHandler
Go to the Configuration tab ‚Üí Permissions Go to Resource-based policy statements ‚Üí Add permissions Add EventBridge Invoke Permission
Service: Select EventBridge (CloudWatch Events) Statement ID: AllowEventBridgeInvokeStateReconstruction Principal: events.amazonaws.com Source ARN: arn:aws:events:ap-southeast-1:218451864254:rule/FastFoodOrderBus/StateReconstructionRule Action: lambda:InvokeFunction** The ARN below is just an example. Replace it with the ARN of the StateReconstructionRule that you created in your AWS account.
9. Click Save to apply the permissions.
This permission configuration is for the StateReconstructionHandler Lambda function. The setup is the same as in the OrderEventProcessor permission configuration earlier, except for the function name and the EventBridge rule it is linked to.
Event Sourcing Context: This rule is essential for our Event Sourcing implementation. When domain events (OrderPlaced, OrderConfirmed, OrderCancelled) are published to the FastFoodOrderBus, they represent state changes in our system. The Lambda function will process these events to: Store them in the event store (DynamoDB) Update read models for queries Potentially trigger side effects or notifications. This enables us to reconstruct the application state from the sequence of events - the core principle of Event Sourcing.

title: Enable CORS
content:
In this step, we will enable Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) on our API Gateway resources. This allows web applications hosted on different domains to securely call our API endpoints.
Step 1: Enable CORS for Each Resource Perform the following steps for each of these resources:
/orders /orders/{id} /orders/confirm /orders/cancel /menu /customers /reconstruct /reconstruct/order /reconstruct/all Select the resource in the API Gateway console. Click ‚Üí Enable CORS.
Configure the CORS settings as follows: Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Content-Type,X-Amz-Date,Authorization,X-Api-Key,X-Amz-Security-Token Access-Control-Allow-Methods: Select all available HTTP methods. Click Enable CORS and replace existing CORS headers. Repeat these steps for each resource to ensure that CORS is properly configured across your entire API.

Monitoring with CloudWatch
content:
Step 1: Access CloudWatch Console In the AWS Management Console, search for CloudWatch. Click CloudWatch to open the monitoring service. Step 2: View Log Groups In the CloudWatch console, navigate to Logs ‚Üí Log groups.
You should see 4 log groups created for your Lambda functions:
/aws/lambda/OrderCommandHandler /aws/lambda/OrderEventProcessor /aws/lambda/OrderQueryHandler /aws/lambda/StateReconstructionHandler Each log group shows the Log class, Retention, and other configuration details. Step 3: Monitor Lambda Function Logs Click on /aws/lambda/StateReconstructionHandler log group.
You can see the log group details including:
Creation time: When the log group was created Retention: Never expire (by default) Stored bytes: Amount of log data stored ARN: Amazon Resource Name for the log group The figure above illustrates the Log events view for the Lambda function StateReconstructionHandler in AWS CloudWatch. Each log entry is displayed in chronological order, containing information about events received from EventBridge (e.g., OrderPlaced, OrderConfirmed, OrderCancelled), the process of rebuilding the order state from the EventStore, and updating the corresponding Read Model. The logs also provide performance metrics such as execution duration, memory usage, and initialization time for the Lambda function. This detailed monitoring enables the development team to verify the correctness of the event processing flow, ensure data consistency, and identify potential performance bottlenecks for optimization.

title: Create Cloudfront Distribution and Apply it to the Website
content:
Create CloudFront Distribution for Global Content Delivery CloudFront is Amazon’s content delivery network (CDN) that speeds up distribution of your static and dynamic web content to users worldwide. In this section, we’ll create a CloudFront distribution for our React application.
Step 1: Access CloudFront Service Navigate to the AWS Management Console and search for “CloudFront” in the search bar. Click on CloudFront to open the service dashboard. Click Create a CloudFront distribution to start the setup process. Step 2: Configure Distribution Settings Distribution Options
Distribution name: Enter a descriptive name for your distribution: fastfood-react-app Description (optional): Add a brief description: FastFood Order System - React App Distribution type: Select Single website or app since we’re deploying a single React application. Custom Domain (Optional) If you have a custom domain, you can configure it here. Otherwise, leave this field empty to use the default CloudFront domain.
Domain (optional): Leave empty for now or enter your custom domain if you have one. Click Check domain if you entered a custom domain to verify availability. Step 3: Specify Origin Configuration The origin is where CloudFront fetches your content from - in this case, your S3 bucket.
Origin type: Select Amazon S3 as we’re serving content from our S3 bucket.
S3 origin: Enter your S3 bucket endpoint: event-sourcing-fastfood-frontend-s3-website-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com
Origin path (optional): Leave as /path or modify if your content is in a specific folder.
Step 4: Configure Security Settings Web Application Firewall (WAF) For this tutorial, we’ll disable WAF to keep costs minimal:
Web Application Firewall (WAF): Select Do not enable security protections. This option is suitable for development and testing environments. For production applications, consider enabling WAF for additional security. Step 5: Review and Create Distribution Review all your configuration settings to ensure they’re correct. Click Next to proceed to the final review page. Click Create distribution to deploy your CloudFront distribution. CloudFront distribution deployment typically takes 15-20 minutes to complete. The status will change from “Deploying” to “Enabled” once ready.
Update S3 Bucket Policy Navigate back to your S3 bucket: event-sourcing-fastfood-frontend Go to the Permissions tab Click on Bucket policy to edit the existing policy Update the policy to include CloudFront access permissions The updated bucket policy should look like this: { "Version": "2012-10-17", "Statement": [ { "Sid": "PublicReadGetObject", "Effect": "Allow", "Principal": "*", "Action": "s3:GetObject", "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::event-sourcing-fastfood-frontend/*" }, { "Sid": "AllowCloudFrontServicePrincipal", "Effect": "Allow", "Principal": { "Service": "cloudfront.amazonaws.com" }, "Action": "s3:GetObject", "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::event-sourcing-fastfood-frontend/*", "Condition": { "StringEquals": { "AWS:SourceArn": "arn:aws:cloudfront::218453064234:distribution/E2MQTT186060K" } } } ] } Click Save changes to apply the updated policy Access Your Application via CloudFront Once the CloudFront distribution is deployed and the bucket policy is updated, you can access your React application through the CloudFront URL. Test the CloudFront Distribution
Copy the Distribution domain name from your CloudFront console (e.g., d26xve6snn0mdw.cloudfront.net) Open a new browser tab and navigate to your CloudFront URL Verify that your Fast Food System loads correctly You should see your React application with:

title: Implement OrderQueryHandler
content:
Next, we will create the OrderQueryHandler Lambda function that handles query requests to retrieve order details from the OrderReadModel.
The steps to create this function are similar to the previous sections.
Step 1: Create Lambda Function Select Author from scratch. Enter the function name: OrderQueryHandler. Choose Runtime: Python 3.12. Choose Architecture: x86_64. Select Use an existing role and pick EventSourcingLambdaRole. Click Create function. Step 2: Implement Function Code Replace the default code with the following: import json import boto3 from boto3.dynamodb.conditions import Key from decimal import Decimal # Initialize DynamoDB dynamodb = boto3.resource('dynamodb') order_table = dynamodb.Table('OrderReadModel') customer_table = dynamodb.Table('CustomerReadModel') menu_items_table = dynamodb.Table('MenuItems') class DecimalEncoder(json.JSONEncoder): def default(self, o): if isinstance(o, Decimal): return float(o) return super(DecimalEncoder, self).default(o) def lambda_handler(event, context): try: http_method = event['httpMethod'] path = event['path'] query_params = event.get('queryStringParameters') or {} print(f"Processing {http_method} {path}") print(f"Query params: {query_params}") if path == '/orders' and http_method == 'GET': return handle_get_orders(query_params) elif path.startswith('/orders/') and http_method == 'GET': order_id = path.split('/')[-1] return handle_get_order(order_id) elif path == '/menu' and http_method == 'GET': return handle_get_menu() elif path == '/customers' and http_method == 'GET': return handle_get_customers(query_params) else: return build_response(404, {'error': 'Endpoint not found'}) except Exception as e: print(f"Error: {str(e)}") import traceback traceback.print_exc() return build_response(500, {'error': 'Internal server error'}) def handle_get_orders(query_params): try: # Get all orders (in production, you'd want pagination) response = order_table.scan( Limit=50 # Limit to 50 orders ) orders = response.get('Items', []) # Sort by createdAt descending orders.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('createdAt', ''), reverse=True) return build_response(200, { 'orders': orders, 'count': len(orders) }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error getting orders: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to get orders'}) def handle_get_order(order_id): try: response = order_table.get_item(Key={'orderId': order_id}) if 'Item' in response: return build_response(200, response['Item']) else: return build_response(404, {'error': 'Order not found'}) except Exception as e: print(f"Error getting order: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to get order'}) def handle_get_menu(): try: response = menu_items_table.scan() items = response.get('Items', []) # Filter only available items available_items = [item for item in items if item.get('available', False)] return build_response(200, { 'items': available_items, 'count': len(available_items) }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error getting menu: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to get menu'}) def handle_get_customers(query_params): try: response = customer_table.scan( Limit=50 # Limit to 50 customers ) customers = response.get('Items', []) return build_response(200, { 'customers': customers, 'count': len(customers) }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error getting customers: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to get customers'}) def build_response(status_code, body): return { 'statusCode': status_code, 'headers': { 'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*', 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods': 'GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS', 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers': 'Content-Type, Authorization' }, 'body': json.dumps(body, cls=DecimalEncoder, default=str) } Click Deploy to save the function code. ‚úÖ The OrderQueryHandler Lambda function is now ready to handle order query requests.

title: Implement State Reconstruction Handler
content:
Finally, we will implement the State Reconstruction Handler Lambda function. This function rebuilds the current state of an order by replaying events from the Event Store, ensuring our system’s state is consistent with the sequence of events.
The creation steps are similar to the previous Lambda functions.
Step 1: Create Lambda Function Select Author from scratch. Enter the function name: StateReconstructionHandler. Choose Runtime: Python 3.12. Choose Architecture: x86_64. Select Use an existing role and pick EventSourcingLambdaRole. Click Create function. Step 2: Implement Function Code Replace the default code with the following: import json import boto3 from boto3.dynamodb.conditions import Key from decimal import Decimal from datetime import datetime # Initialize DynamoDB dynamodb = boto3.resource('dynamodb') event_store_table = dynamodb.Table('EventStore') order_table = dynamodb.Table('OrderReadModel') class DecimalEncoder(json.JSONEncoder): def default(self, o): if isinstance(o, Decimal): return float(o) return super(DecimalEncoder, self).default(o) def lambda_handler(event, context): """ State Reconstruction Handler - HTTP request: rebuild theo API path - EventBridge event: rebuild ngay cho order li√™n quan """ try: print("Received event:", json.dumps(event)) http_method = None path = None body = {} # Tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p API Gateway REST API if 'httpMethod' in event: http_method = event['httpMethod'] path = event.get('path') body = json.loads(event.get('body') or "{}") # Tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p API Gateway HTTP API (v2 payload) elif event.get('requestContext', {}).get('http', {}).get('method'): http_method = event['requestContext']['http']['method'] path = event.get('rawPath') body = json.loads(event.get('body') or "{}") # Tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p EventBridge event elif event.get("detail-type") in ["OrderPlaced", "OrderConfirmed", "OrderCancelled"]: order_id = event.get("detail", {}).get("orderId") if not order_id: print("No orderId in event, skipping reconstruction.") return build_response(400, {"error": "orderId not found in event"}) print(f"Rebuilding state for orderId from EventBridge: {order_id}") events = get_events_for_order(order_id) if not events: return build_response(404, {"error": f"No events found for order {order_id}"}) reconstructed_state = reconstruct_order_state(events) update_read_model(reconstructed_state) return build_response(200, { "message": f"State rebuilt from EventBridge event for order {order_id}", "orderId": order_id, "eventsProcessed": len(events), "reconstructedState": reconstructed_state }) else: print("Unknown event source, skipping.") return build_response(200, {"message": "Event ignored"}) # X·ª≠ l√Ω HTTP request nh∆∞ c≈© print(f"Processing {http_method} {path}") if path == '/reconstruct/order' and http_method == 'POST': return handle_reconstruct_order(body) elif path == '/reconstruct/all' and http_method == 'POST': return handle_reconstruct_all_orders(body) elif path == '/reconstruct/validate' and http_method == 'POST': return handle_validate_reconstruction(body) else: return build_response(404, {'error': 'Endpoint not found'}) except Exception as e: print(f"Error: {str(e)}") import traceback traceback.print_exc() return build_response(500, {'error': 'Internal server error'}) def handle_reconstruct_order(body): """Reconstruct a single order from events""" order_id = body.get('orderId') if not order_id: return build_response(400, {'error': 'orderId is required'}) try: # Get all events for this order events = get_events_for_order(order_id) if not events: return build_response(404, {'error': 'No events found for order'}) # Reconstruct state from events reconstructed_state = reconstruct_order_state(events) # Update read model update_read_model(reconstructed_state) return build_response(200, { 'message': 'Order state reconstructed successfully', 'orderId': order_id, 'eventsProcessed': len(events), 'reconstructedState': reconstructed_state }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error reconstructing order {order_id}: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to reconstruct order'}) def handle_reconstruct_all_orders(body): """Reconstruct all orders from events""" max_orders = body.get('maxOrders', 100) # Limit for safety try: # Get all unique aggregate IDs from event store response = event_store_table.scan( ProjectionExpression='aggregateId', Limit=max_orders ) order_ids = list(set([item['aggregateId'] for item in response.get('Items', [])])) reconstructed_orders = [] errors = [] for order_id in order_ids: try: events = get_events_for_order(order_id) if events: reconstructed_state = reconstruct_order_state(events) update_read_model(reconstructed_state) reconstructed_orders.append({ 'orderId': order_id, 'eventsProcessed': len(events) }) except Exception as e: errors.append({ 'orderId': order_id, 'error': str(e) }) return build_response(200, { 'message': f'Reconstructed {len(reconstructed_orders)} orders', 'reconstructedOrders': reconstructed_orders, 'errors': errors }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error reconstructing all orders: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to reconstruct orders'}) def handle_validate_reconstruction(body): """Validate reconstruction by comparing with current read model""" order_id = body.get('orderId') if not order_id: return build_response(400, {'error': 'orderId is required'}) try: # Get current read model state current_state = order_table.get_item(Key={'orderId': order_id}).get('Item') # Get reconstructed state from events events = get_events_for_order(order_id) reconstructed_state = reconstruct_order_state(events) # Compare states validation_result = compare_states(current_state, reconstructed_state) return build_response(200, { 'orderId': order_id, 'isValid': validation_result['isValid'], 'differences': validation_result['differences'], 'currentState': current_state, 'reconstructedState': reconstructed_state }) except Exception as e: print(f"Error validating reconstruction: {str(e)}") return build_response(500, {'error': 'Failed to validate reconstruction'}) def get_events_for_order(order_id): """Get all events for a specific order, sorted by timestamp""" try: response = event_store_table.query( IndexName='AggregateIndex', # Assuming GSI on aggregateId KeyConditionExpression=Key('aggregateId').eq(order_id), ScanIndexForward=True # Sort by timestamp ascending ) events = response.get('Items', []) # Sort by timestamp to ensure correct order events.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('timestamp', '')) return events except Exception as e: print(f"Error getting events for order {order_id}: {str(e)}") # Fallback to scan if GSI doesn't exist response = event_store_table.scan( FilterExpression=Key('aggregateId').eq(order_id) ) events = response.get('Items', []) events.sort(key=lambda x: x.get('timestamp', '')) return events def reconstruct_order_state(events): """Reconstruct order state by replaying events""" state = { 'orderId': None, 'status': None, 'customerName': None, 'customerPhone': None, 'customerAddress': None, 'items': [], 'totalAmount': Decimal('0'), 'createdAt': None, 'updatedAt': None, 'confirmedAt': None, 'cancelledAt': None, 'cancelReason': None, 'estimatedDelivery': None, 'eventHistory': [] } for event in events: event_type = event.get('eventType') event_data = event.get('eventData', {}) timestamp = event.get('timestamp') # Track event history state['eventHistory'].append({ 'eventType': event_type, 'timestamp': timestamp, 'eventId': event.get('eventId') }) if event_type == 'OrderPlaced': state['orderId'] = event_data.get('orderId') state['customerName'] = event_data.get('customerName') state['customerPhone'] = event_data.get('customerPhone') state['customerAddress'] = event_data.get('customerAddress') state['items'] = event_data.get('items', []) state['totalAmount'] = Decimal(str(event_data.get('totalAmount', 0))) state['status'] = 'PLACED' state['createdAt'] = timestamp state['updatedAt'] = timestamp elif event_type == 'OrderConfirmed': state['status'] = 'CONFIRMED' state['confirmedAt'] = event_data.get('confirmedAt') state['estimatedDelivery'] = event_data.get('estimatedDelivery') state['updatedAt'] = timestamp elif event_type == 'OrderCancelled': state['status'] = 'CANCELLED' state['cancelledAt'] = event_data.get('cancelledAt') state['cancelReason'] = event_data.get('reason') state['updatedAt'] = timestamp # Add more event types as needed return state def update_read_model(state): """Update the read model with reconstructed state""" try: # Remove event history for read model read_model_state = {k: v for k, v in state.items() if k != 'eventHistory'} order_table.put_item(Item=read_model_state) print(f"Updated read model for order {state['orderId']}") except Exception as e: print(f"Error updating read model: {str(e)}") raise def compare_states(current_state, reconstructed_state): """Compare current read model state with reconstructed state""" differences = [] if not current_state: return { 'isValid': False, 'differences': ['Current state not found in read model'] } # Remove event history from comparison reconstructed_compare = {k: v for k, v in reconstructed_state.items() if k != 'eventHistory'} # Compare key fields compare_fields = ['orderId', 'status', 'customerName', 'customerPhone', 'totalAmount', 'createdAt', 'confirmedAt', 'cancelledAt'] for field in compare_fields: current_value = current_state.get(field) reconstructed_value = reconstructed_compare.get(field) # Handle Decimal comparison if isinstance(current_value, Decimal) and isinstance(reconstructed_value, Decimal): if current_value != reconstructed_value: differences.append(f"{field}: current={current_value}, reconstructed={reconstructed_value}") elif str(current_value) != str(reconstructed_value): differences.append(f"{field}: current={current_value}, reconstructed={reconstructed_value}") return { 'isValid': len(differences) == 0, 'differences': differences } def build_response(status_code, body): return { 'statusCode': status_code, 'headers': { 'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin': '*', 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods': 'GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS', 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers': 'Content-Type, Authorization' }, 'body': json.dumps(body, cls=DecimalEncoder, default=str) } Click Deploy to save the function code. ‚úÖ The StateReconstructionHandler Lambda function is now ready to reconstruct order state by replaying events.

title: Implement EventBridge Pipeline
content:
In this section, we will set up the EventBridge infrastructure to support the Event Sourcing architecture of our fast food ordering system. This involves creating a dedicated custom Event Bus to capture and route all domain events related to orders, such as OrderPlaced, OrderConfirmed, and OrderCancelled.
By defining precise event rules, we ensure that each event is delivered to the appropriate Lambda functions responsible for processing and updating the system‚Äôs state asynchronously. Additionally, we will create an SNS Topic to broadcast notifications triggered by these events.
This EventBridge pipeline is a crucial component of our Event Sourcing design, enabling reliable, decoupled, and real-time event-driven processing, which allows the system to reconstruct state from events and respond promptly to changes.

title: Config API Gateway
content:
In this section, we will configure Amazon API Gateway to serve as the front door for our fast food ordering system. API Gateway will act as the RESTful interface that clients use to interact with our Event Sourcing architecture, providing secure and scalable access to our Lambda functions. We will create a new API Gateway that exposes endpoints for order management operations such as creating orders, retrieving order status, and handling customer requests. The API Gateway will integrate seamlessly with our Lambda functions, which in turn publish events to our EventBridge pipeline. Additionally, we will enable Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) to allow web applications from different domains to interact with our API, ensuring compatibility with modern web development practices. Finally, we will deploy the API to make it accessible to external clients. This API Gateway configuration is essential for providing a clean, RESTful interface to our event-driven architecture, enabling clients to trigger domain events while maintaining proper separation of concerns between the presentation layer and our Event Sourcing implementation.
